Award.AwardTitle: Societal resilience and interaction with the environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Cameron L. McNeil will lead an international team of scholars investigating the role of environmental factors in the collapse of ancient Maya city-states. The collapse, which occurred within lowland regions of the Maya area between AD 790 and 950, has been the focus of extensive debate. Numerous hypotheses have been proposed to explain it, including warfare, climate change, top-heavy political systems, and natural disasters. But in particular, environmental degradation, or deforestation, has found widespread support as an explanation for the collapse. Archaeological and environmental data from the Copan Valley in Honduras are frequently invoked to argue that the ancient Maya destroyed their environment and precipitated the collapse of their society. According to this view, population pressure drove the Maya to deforest their lands and thereby instigate large-scale erosion, contributing to the political and demographic collapse. This project will use research techniques from a variety of scientific disciplines to generate new data on human-environmental interaction in the Copan Valley, which will shed new light on the environmental degradation theory of the collapse. The project will also address a contrasting hypothesis: that at the peak of their civilization the Maya actually implemented sustainable land-use practices, implying that deforestation was not a major factor in the collapse. Preliminary data collected by Dr. McNeil suggests that the Maya at Copan had, in fact, established a long term sustainable environmental equilibrium and degradation was not the cause of social change. The project has a strong commitment to education of both US and Honduran students. It has an active history of including both US graduate and undergraduate students in the research. Training Honduran students serves to raise the level of archaeological knowledge within the country and contributes to an appreciation of and a commitment to protecting the nation's historic and prehistoric heritage.


The majority of the data collection will be centered on the archaeological site of RÃ­o Amarillo, an ancient Maya town in the Copan Valley, and the alluvial plain to its west. The goal of the research is to collect a variety of independent and complementary data sets amenable to the analysis of past human-environmental interactions. In particular, the project will undertake the analysis of pollen and phytoliths from sediment cores extracted from a body of water; starch and phytolith analysis from ground stones, lithics, and ceramics; the identification of charred macroremains recovered from archaeological excavations; stable carbon isotopes and phytoliths to determine the vegetative histories of the fields around the site; ground penetrating radar (GPR) to uncover signs of drainage networks; 3D imaging of the landscape with near-infrared sensors to look for field modifications; and recording modern pollen rain to assist in interpreting ancient pollen signatures. Each of these forms of data has the potential to provide indications of the extent of environmental degradation created by human populations over time. Results from this research will complement the analysis of artifacts and settlement plans acquired from archaeological excavations, providing a detailed record of human-environmental interaction in this area. The project will provide new data and new insights concerning the state of the landscape in the Copan Valley at the time of the collapse.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation grant #1431002 supported the Proyecto Arqueológico Río Amarillo, Copán (PARAC) from 2014-2017.  The primary focus of this research was the investigation of ancient agricultural practices, including land transformation, in the far eastern section of the Copan Valley: The Rio Amarillo East Pocket.  The hypothesis that a prime mover behind the collapse of the ancient Maya city-states was the deforestation (and other forms of over-exploitation) of the environment has gained popularity since the 1970s. Copan, in particular, has been held up as a type-site for this belief. Work by the applicant called this hypothesis into question through the analysis of a sediment core taken from a pond near the center of ancient Copan that demonstrated there was less deforestation in the Late Classic (C.E. 600-850) period than in the Early Classic (C.E. 400-600) period suggesting the alternate hypothesis that the Maya were in fact carefully and sustainably managing the landscape of the Copan Valley during the Late Classic.  The PARAC project was designed to investigate the latter hypothesis further in an area of the valley where occupation is still low and which contains a Type 4 and Type 3 site. Funds from the NSF were used for a range of analytical approaches to investigate how the ancient Maya interacted with their environment during the Late Classic and Postclassic periods. The majority of the data collection was centered on the archaeological site of Río Amarillo, an ancient Maya town, and the largest center in the eastern end of the Copan Valley, and a smaller nearby site, Quebrada Piedras Negras, which is located across a large fertile plain sparsely dotted with house mounds.

Using NSF funds project members analyzed local soils to uncover the history of past land use, conducted ground penetrating radar delineating signs of ancient canals and drains, used infrared photography shot from a unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) also to discover canals and drains, revealing pre-Columbian land transformation designed by the ancient Maya to increase agricultural output.  Additionally, the use of the UAV allowed the project to create a data set from which GIS analysis can be conducted to determine the relationship between structures and natural resources.  Sediment cores were extracted from two bodies of water to reveal patterns of deforestation and reforestation in this area.  One of them contains 9,400 years of environmental history. More than two thousand soil samples were floated to determine the food resources of the inhabitants. Analysis of these samples will take some years to finish. A sample of vessels and stone tools recovered in excavations were analyzed for phytoliths, starches, and chemical residues to uncover the food sources prized by the ancient inhabitants of this area (much of this work is ongoing). Unfortunately, chemical residues do not appear to have survived the highly-acidic local soil, but there is an abundance of wood and seed charcoal from middens. Overall, the analyses have produced, or will produce, large data sets that will be stored on the Digital Archaeological Record.

The project has provided professional development opportunities to both graduate and undergraduate students. Four students completed MA theses using data collected from work supported by the NSF.  And at least one more will obtain an MA from this segment of the project in the near future.  Some of the data collected will also be used by doctoral students at the Graduate Center, CUNY.  A large number of students have participated in the various project activities conducted with NSF funds, including: 3 graduate students from The Graduate Center, The City University of New York (CUNY); 5 undergraduate students from Lehman College, CUNY; 1 graduate student and 2 undergraduates from Brigham Young University; 5 students from the University of Ghent; 2 from Yale University, 1 from the University of Arkansas, 1 from the University of Southern Mississippi, 2 from Northern Kentucky University, 13 from the National University of Honduras (UNAH); 1 Honduran student from Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala (USAC); and 1 Honduran student from Universidad del Valle de Guatemala.  Two Lehman College, CUNY undergraduates who received REUs through the project have gone on to be awarded fully-funded fellowships for their doctoral education in Anthropology. One of these students was also awarded an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship. In addition, 2 Honduran project workers whose jobs were funded through this grant are pursuing high school degrees with an interest in pursuing a B.A. in Archaeology.

When the analysis of the large body of data collected in this project is complete, it is hoped that much more will be known about the resources available to the inhabitants of the Rio Amarillo East Pocket of the Copan Valley and the manner in which the ancient Maya manipulated their environment to feed the burgeoning population of the Late Classic period.
